question: What are the player options that Kentavious Caldwell-Pope and Reggie Jackson need to decide on, and by when?
contexts: ["Denver doesn't have much time to get over the sting of losing Game 7 at home and getting bounced in the second round of the playoffs. Kentavious Caldwell-Pope, a key contributor to the Nuggets' 2023 championship, has a $15.4 million player option to decide on by June 29. And Reggie Jackson has a $5.3 million player option to decide on by June 25. The Nuggets' championship window remains open as long as MVP Nikola Jokic is healthy and Jamal Murray and Aaron Gordon are extension eligible. Denver will also have to figure out how to improve its bench. After losing Bruce Brown and Jeff Green last offseason, the Nuggets went young, but they relied heavily on their starters and looked like a tired team at the end of the season. -- Ohm Youngmisuk"]
ground_truth: Kentavious Caldwell-Pope has a $15.4 million player option to decide on by June 29, and Reggie Jackson has a $5.3 million player option to decide on by June 25.

question: What financial impact does the new contract have on the Lions compared to using the franchise tag for Goff?
contexts: ["Had the Lions let Goff play out his 2024 deal (roughly $27 million in cash) and then given him the nonexclusive franchise tag in 2025 and again in 2026 and again in 2027, that would be roughly 1 year/$27 million or 2/$69M or 3/$120M or 4/$193M, based on OverTheCap's 2025 franchise tag projections and assuming a 20% raise each year after that for future tags. With this deal, it's either 1/$119M or 2/$154M or 3/$172M or 4/$194M or 5/$241M. The Lions lost their flexibility and now need Goff to play on this contract through 2027 just to break even -- or through 2028 to get any value -- relative to the tag."]
ground_truth: The new contract impacts the Lions financially by reducing their flexibility. They now need Goff to play on this contract through 2027 just to break even, or through 2028 to get any value, relative to using the franchise tag.

question: Why did Willie Mays think Bob Gibson was crazy for not wearing glasses while pitching?
contexts: ['Torre "[First baseman] Bill White was playing for the Cardinals. He and Gibby [Hall of Fame pitcher Bob Gibson] went to San Francisco in the offseason. Bill was invited to Willie\'s house for dinner, and he asked Gibby if he wanted to go. Bob said, \'I\'d love to go, I\'ve never met Willie Mays.\' They ring the doorbell. Willie comes to the door. In the offseason, Gibby always wore glasses, but he didn\'t wear them when he pitched. So Willie opens the door, he says hello to Bill, then he says, \'Who is this?\' Bill said, \'Willie, this is Bob Gibson.\' Willie didn\'t say hello to him, all he said was, \'You wear glasses!? And you don\'t wear them when you pitch? Are you crazy? You\'re going to hurt somebody!\'"']
ground_truth: Willie Mays thought Bob Gibson was crazy for not wearing glasses while pitching because he believed that not wearing glasses could lead to Gibson hurting somebody.

question: Why is it important for every starter and rotation player on the Celtics to be a volume shooter?
contexts: ["On paper, the Celtics do not appear to make much use of the paint. They don't get to the rim or the foul line much. They are an average offensive rebounding team. They lead the league in 3s by a mile. But volume is one ingredient in Boston cracking that code. If you are going to play this way, you have to really do it. Every starter and hopefully everyone in the rotation has to be a volume shooter. If the NBA is a variance game now, put yourself in position to win it."]
ground_truth: It is important for every starter and rotation player on the Celtics to be a volume shooter because if the NBA is a variance game now, putting yourself in position to win it requires a high volume of 3-point shots. This strategy is essential for the Celtics as they lead the league in 3s by a mile.

question: Where did Willie Howard Mays Jr. grow up?
contexts: ["Mays was born into that. His mother was a great athlete. His father was a great center fielder, too. His son, Willie Howard Mays Jr., was so advanced growing up in Westfield, Alabama, that he played against 18-year-olds when he was 10. Mays played for the Birmingham Black Barons of the Negro Leagues when he was 15. In 1950, at age 18, he signed with the New York Giants for $15,000 (he bought a car but couldn't drive it, so it became a car that his community drove). He spent two years in the minor leagues, then joined the Giants in May 1951 just after turning 20 years old. Durocher put him in the No. 3 spot in the order and, after a 1-for-25 start, he went on to win the Rookie of the Year Award and helped the Giants overcome a 13Â½-game deficit against the Dodgers to win the pennant. He was oblivious to the pressure. He was as natural a talent as anyone had ever seen."]
ground_truth: Willie Howard Mays Jr. grew up in Westfield, Alabama.
metadata: [{'site': 'espn', 'country': 'us', 'title': 'Why there will never be another MLB player like Willie Mays', 'author': 'Tim Kurkjian', 'content_publish_date': 'Jun 18, 2024, 10:34 PM ET'}]

question: How did the compressed schedule from 2019-20 through 2021-22 contribute to recent parity in the NBA?
contexts: ["The way the NBA's stoppage of play for the COVID-19 pandemic compressed the league's schedule from 2019-20 through 2021-22 is an often overlooked explanation for recent parity. Consider that from August 2020 to June 2022, the league played three full postseasons in a span of 22 months. Teams such as the Celtics that played deep into the NBA's 2020 bubble playoffs were hit hardest. It's surely no coincidence that only one of the four teams that reached the conference finals that year (the Denver Nuggets) won a playoff series in 2021, and none got back to the conference finals -- just the fourth time that had happened since the playoffs expanded to 16 teams in 1984."]
ground_truth: The compressed schedule from 2019-20 through 2021-22 contributed to recent parity in the NBA by forcing teams to play three full postseasons in a span of 22 months. This intense schedule particularly affected teams that played deep into the 2020 bubble playoffs, such as the Celtics, making it difficult for them to maintain high performance levels. As a result, only one of the four teams that reached the conference finals in 2020 won a playoff series in 2021, and none returned to the conference finals.
metadata: [{'site': 'espn', 'country': 'us', 'title': "Parity or dynasty? The Boston Celtics' chances at breaking a modern NBA trend", 'author': 'Kevin Pelton', 'content_publish_date': 'Jun 18, 2024, 08:00 AM ET'}]

question: How many second-round picks do the Bulls have available?
contexts: ['The Bulls owe a first-round pick to the Spurs that is top-10 protected in 2025 and top-eight protected in 2026 or 2027. They have a first-round pick from Portland that is top-14 protected over the next four years. If the first is not conveyed, the Trail Blazers will send a 2028 second. The Bulls have three second-round picks available.']
ground_truth: The Bulls have three second-round picks available.
metadata: [{'site': 'espn', 'country': 'us', 'title': 'NBA free agency 2024: Priorities, player needs for 30 teams', 'author': 'Bobby Marks', 'content_publish_date': 'Jun 13, 2024, 07:05 AM ET'}]

question: Why is Hill considered the most feared receiver in the league?
contexts: ["Why he's the best at his age: Hill is arguably the most feared receiver in the league since Randy Moss, due to his blistering speed and explosive play ability. He tied for the NFL lead in receptions of 20-plus yards (25) and touchdown grabs (13) last season. He's a vertical threat from both boundary and slot alignments, and the pre-snap movement in Mike McDaniel's system allows him to get free releases into his routes."]
ground_truth: Hill is considered the most feared receiver in the league due to his blistering speed and explosive play ability. He tied for the NFL lead in receptions of 20-plus yards (25) and touchdown grabs (13) last season. Additionally, he is a vertical threat from both boundary and slot alignments, and the pre-snap movement in Mike McDaniel's system allows him to get free releases into his routes.
metadata: [{'site': 'espn', 'country': 'us', 'title': 'Best NFL, college, high school football players by age 14-40', 'author': 'Matt Bowen and Jordan Reid and Billy Tucker', 'content_publish_date': 'Jun 13, 2024, 06:25 AM ET'}]

question: How did last year's Men's College World Series impact the first round draft picks in the MLB draft?
contexts: ["Last year's crop of prospects playing in Omaha was historic, just like the top of the 2023 MLB draft, in part because the overlap was complete. The Men's College World Series had 10 of the first 15 college players drafted last season, all in the first round. It also featured seven more players projected to go in the first round this year."]
ground_truth: Last year's Men's College World Series had a significant impact on the first round draft picks in the MLB draft, featuring 10 of the first 15 college players drafted last season, all in the first round.

question: How can an injury in the WNBA lead to someone else starting to blossom and gain confidence?
contexts: ['"[Injuries] are part of the WNBA, unfortunately," Miller said. "You just have to have the mentality of next person up and rally around it. Does an injury open a door for someone else to really start to blossom and gain confidence? You look at my time in Connecticut ... someone went down, someone else stepped up.']
ground_truth: An injury in the WNBA can lead to someone else starting to blossom and gain confidence because it opens a door for another player to step up and take on a larger role. This opportunity allows the new player to gain experience and confidence.

question: What right do the Grizzlies have regarding the less favorable of Phoenix, Orlando, and Washington's first-round picks in 2026?
contexts: ['The Grizzlies control their own first over the next seven years. They also have the right to swap their own 2026 first for the less favorable of Phoenix, Orlando and Washington. The Grizzlies also have the right to swap their own 2030 first for the less favorable one among the Suns and Wizards. Memphis has six second-round picks available.']
ground_truth: The Grizzlies have the right to swap their own 2026 first for the less favorable of Phoenix, Orlando, and Washington's first-round picks.
